instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00928: What is 820-00928? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V Not turning on
threads.message:
Client brought in a macbook - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that wasn't turning on.

It takes in 20V  .1A- .8A fluctuating on all 4 ports
Liquid damage on <CHIP>U3906</CHIP> area 
No Voltage on Big coils 

Cleaned up corrosion
Lifted <CHIP>U3906</CHIP> removed corrosion. 
With a new known good battery it takes 2-3A - cpu doesnt get hot

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is present
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> is present
CPU Lines not present / 2OHMS to ground
SMC Reset/Bypass made both fans spin at max w/ new battery but no display

Seems like its trying to turn on but cant complete the sequence

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V Not turning on
threads.message:
Do you get CPU core voltage, when the board turns on (SMC reset/bypass)?
If yes, what is the voltage after 10-15s?
Also check USB activity, in this case.
Did you try known good BIOS?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V Not turning on
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>CPUCORE_BOOT1</SIGNAL>: 4.8V
<SIGNAL>CPUCORE_BOOT2</SIGNAL>: 4.8v
<SIGNAL>CPUCORE_BOOT3</SIGNAL>: 4.8v
<SIGNAL>CPUCORE_BP1</SIGNAL>: 4.8v
<SIGNAL>CPUCORE_PHASE1</SIGNAL>: 0v
<SIGNAL>CPUCORE_PHASE2</SIGNAL>: 0v
<SIGNAL>CPUCORE_ISNS1_N</SIGNAL>: 0v
<SIGNAL>CPUCORE_SW1</SIGNAL>: 0v

There is USB Activity 
I have not tried a known good bios yet

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V Not turning on
threads.message:
Impossible to get USB activity, without CPU core voltage.
Don't confuse USB power with activity!

If no CPU core, which other voltage appears on the board, when fans spin?
Check on all big coils.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V Not turning on
threads.message:
The USB gets power but no communication/activity.

None of the big CPU coils get voltage on them 

L7900: 1.2v
L8410: 3.3v
L7960: 0.95v
L8000: 1.0v

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>: 11.34
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>: 3.29
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3.3
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>: 5.1

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V Not turning on
threads.message:
Did you check L8020 too?
No voltage at L7330?

<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> goes high?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V Not turning on
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V Not turning on
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is required to enable CPU power supplies.
Check <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> (1 OF 10) power good signals.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V Not turning on
threads.message:
These are the signals I could find test points for -

<SIGNAL>P1V8SUS_PGOOD</SIGNAL>: 3.3V
<SIGNAL>CPU_VCCST_PWRGD</SIGNAL>: .04V
<SIGNAL>P5VS4_PGOOD</SIGNAL>: 3.2V
<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is good

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V Not turning on
threads.message:
Power good signals from the power supplies controlled by <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> directly, are not routed externally.
So check presence of voltages from pages 71 & 72.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V Not turning on
threads.message:
Took a second look over the board & noticed <CHIP>U8295</CHIP> getting hot. Removed the chip and Pin 5&6 were short (<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_LEFT</SIGNAL>)

Used an infrared camera and sent 1.8v through the line and it led to <CAPACITOR>C2991</CAPACITOR>(<SIGNAL>PP3V3_TBT_X_S0</SIGNAL>). Removed the Cap but short is still present.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V Not turning on
threads.message:
You can inject until 3.5V without problems.
<CHIP>U2800</CHIP> is the first suspect there.
Lift its metal shield to properly check if heats up.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V Not turning on
threads.message:
<CHIP>U2800</CHIP> was heating up after injecting 3V into the into Pin 5/6 on <CHIP>U8295</CHIP>

Replaced <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> and everything is looking good. Thank you for the help.
